messages.text: It should be pretty good for this. How many channels do you need? If it's something like 16 channels, then I'd recommend using an `SVector{16,T}` as the element type of your arrays and writing your algorithms for that datatype.

messages.text:
Hi,

I would like to warp an image by the log-polar transform but I have troubles to make it work. Can someone give me a push please?

```using CoordinateTransformations, ImageTransformations
struct Retinotopy <: Transformation; end
struct InvRetinotopy <: Transformation; end
function (::Retinotopy)(x)
    length(x) == 2 || error("Polar transform takes a 2D coordinate")

    Polar(log(hypot(x[1], x[2])), atan(x[2], x[1]))
end

function (::InvRetinotopy)(x::Polar)
    s,c = sincos(x.Œ∏)
    SVector(exp(x.r) * c, exp(x.r) * s)
end
(t::InvRetinotopy)(x) = t(Polar(x[1], x[2]))
Base.inv(::Retinotopy) = InvRetinotopy()

tfm = Retinotopy()
imgw = warp(img, tfm);```

elements.text:
Hi,

I would like to warp an image by the log-polar transform but I have troubles to make it work. Can someone give me a push please?

using CoordinateTransformations, ImageTransformations
struct Retinotopy <: Transformation; end
struct InvRetinotopy <: Transformation; end
function (::Retinotopy)(x)
    length(x) == 2 || error("Polar transform takes a 2D coordinate")

    Polar(log(hypot(x[1], x[2])), atan(x[2], x[1]))
end

function (::InvRetinotopy)(x::Polar)
    s,c = sincos(x.Œ∏)
    SVector(exp(x.r) * c, exp(x.r) * s)
end
(t::InvRetinotopy)(x) = t(Polar(x[1], x[2]))
Base.inv(::Retinotopy) = InvRetinotopy()

tfm = Retinotopy()
imgw = warp(img, tfm);

messages.text: I wrote a small reader package for Phantom high speed video .cine files, and I'm trying to figure out where it fits/which interfaces it should conform to before (/if) I register it

elements.text: I wrote a small reader package for Phantom high speed video .cine files, and I'm trying to figure out where it fits/which interfaces it should conform to before (/if) I register it

messages.text: ffmpeg (and thus VideoIO) supports .cine files, but downgrades them to a bit depth of 8 bits, while I want access to my camera's full 12 bit range. The high framerate also violates the real-time assumptions made by VideoIO (indexing by the time in seconds? I'm dealing with microseconds!), and the files can be many gigabytes, which makes it prohibitively expensive to load them in a non-streaming manner

messages.text: <https://github.com/stillyslalom/CineFiles.jl>

Can you give it an array-like interface? Typically I aim for `img = load("somefile.ext")` and then `img` is an `AbstractArray` with my data. NRRD, for example, uses mmap to load TB-sized files effortlessly.

It would be great if some VideoIO users could review the changelog, and perhaps even try out master before we release v0.9

Feedback very much welcomed

<https://github.com/JuliaIO/VideoIO.jl/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md|https://github.com/JuliaIO/VideoIO.jl/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>

messages.text:
Hi everyone! I am a Julia newcomer and I am wondering what image processing library to use. I saw there exist several options and considered the following:
1. A combination of <https://juliaimages.org/ImageFiltering.jl/stable/#ImageFiltering.jl-1|ImageFiltering> / <https://github.com/JuliaImages/ImageMorphology.jl|ImageMorphology> / <https://github.com/JuliaImages/ImageTransformations.jl|ImageTransformations> 
2. <https://juliaimages.org/stable/|JuliaImages>
3. <https://docs.opencv.org/master/d8/da4/tutorial_julia.html|OpenCV binding>
Roughly, my use-case is the following: I am trying to automatically learn playing <https://paperswithcode.com/dataset/arcade-learning-environment|Atari 2600 games>. I would need a library including a large variety of image filters to which fast calls can be performed as learning would require many samples + I would need to chain several filters together. As you can see, images on Atari 2600 are relatively small and unrealistic (no noise, objects rarely overlap and pixels of 1 object almost always have the same color).
Any thought about this? Thanks in advance! :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: Papers with Code - Arcade Learning Environment Dataset
attachments.text: The Arcade Learning Environment (ALE) is an object-oriented framework that allows researchers to develop AI agents for Atari 2600 games. It is built on top of the Atari 2600 emulator Stella and separates the details of emulation from agent design.
attachments.fallback: Papers with Code - Arcade Learning Environment Dataset

Any thought about this? Thanks in advance!
